The Poverty-Environment Initiative (PEI) of the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) is a global programme that supports country-led efforts to mainstream poverty-environment linkages into national development and sub-national development planning, from policymaking to budgeting, implementation and monitoring.

With both financial and technical support, PEI assists government decision-makers and a wide range of other stakeholders to manage the environment in a way that improves livelihoods and leads to sustainable growth. The PEI works with key government partners to raise awareness, influence policy making and strengthen the mainstreaming of poverty-environment into budget processes, sector programmes and sub-national planning. The overall aim is to bring about lasting institutional change and to catalyse key actors to increase investment in pro-poor environmental and natural resource management.

PEI in Bhutan is designed as a joint programme to channel multi-donor support to strengthen good governance and promote inclusive green socio-economic development at the local level. The programme has three major components:

1. Inclusive and equitable socio-economic development at the local level -will focus on strengthening the system of fiscal decentralization, including Annual Capital Grants and Performance-based Grants for equitable local socio- economic development.

2. Conservation and sustainable use of environment at the local level - will focus on institutionalizing responsibility and knowledge for mainstreaming gender, environment, climate, disaster, and poverty (GECDP) issues; monitoring, advocacy and training to enhance the effectiveness and sustainability of GECDP mainstreaming; and fostering enabling conditions for green development at the local level. 

3. Strengthening good governance - will focus on improving the utilization of integrated national monitoring and evaluation system by local governments; strengthening access to demand-driven capacity development for LGs; and enhancing public participation, transparency, and accountability for LGs.

To work with the Poverty Analysis and Monitoring Wing to develop capacities and carry out analysis of development policies to allow for sound policymaking. This include training and equipping of individuals and institutional capacity building to conduct analytical work, provide policy options and maintain dialogue among the agencies and CSOs. The work will form part of a comprehensive capacity building programme.

The Government of Indonesia (GoI) has been striving to achieve a transition from the current brown economy to green economy development pathways. To realize this, it is central to integrate the principles of green economy into the processes of policy decision making, namely planning, budgeting, monitoring and evaluation, and audit.  The Green Finance for Development (GFD) project has been requested by the Ministry of Finance to focus on the greening of the budget process. The project builds on the Mitigation Fiscal Framework (MFF) prepared by the Fiscal Policy Office of the Ministry of Finance with UNDP support.   
The project targets three thematic areas: climate change mitigation, adaptation/disaster risk reduction and biodiversity. The aim of the project is to strengthen the capacities of the Government of Indonesia to green the budget by focusing on the development and implementation of green fiscal frameworks for the RAN GRK (climate mitigation), RAN API (climate adaptation) and IBSAP (biodiversity), The project provides an overarching chapeau to accommodate three separate, yet highly complementary regional/global projects: the Poverty and Environment Initiative (PEI); Biodiversity Finance Initiative (BIOFIN); and Strengthening the Governance of Climate Finance to Benefit the Poor and Vulnerable funded by SIDA. During the implementation, in addition to PEI grant of USD 350,000, the project will be supported by in-kind contribution from two other projects; UDP (BIOFIN) in the amount of USD 700,000, and Climate Finance in the amount of USD 250,000.

The Project will help mainstream the dimension of poverty and environment into different scales (national, regional and local) of the National Planning System, through the integration of ecosystem services and the social demand for environmental goods and services, with a territorial development approach, promoted in planning processes.  At national level it presents the definition of specific studies for the valuation of the role of ecosystems within the framework of country agenda, K'atun, our Guatemala 2032, the execution of seminars for the coming together of actors from the environmental sector and of development planning, the formation of an inter-institutional coordinating commission and the writing of the chapter on valuation of national ecosystem services.  Additionally mechanisms to generate public awareness and improve and capacities to strengthen appreciation about territorial planning and its link to ecosystem services of the territory will be developed.  
For the design of the dry corridor regional plan, dialogue and coordination spaces will be promoted with strategic actors from the region to generate information about the potentialities of the territory starting from the results of the sub-global evaluation and the formulation of a collective territorial development plan.  Additionally a group of investment projects at profile level with the identification of possible financing sources (public, private, public-private investment) will be created.      

At local level, three plans of territorial planning and management will be created and implemented, starting with the protection and use of the coastal ecosystem of the Chiquimulilla canal sub-region looking to facilitate the implementation of a group of projects and the formulation of institutional agreements and of a local regulation involving public actors (municipalities and development councils), private and community.

The objective of the proposed project is to support rural families beneficiaries of the "Tekopora" Conditional Cash Transfer Program located in the buffer zone of the Caazapa National Park for their effective socio-economic integration into the local and regional economies on the basis of sustainable agricultural production and inclusive markets; and participation in the local development agendas, thereby improving their livelihoods.  The proposed project will pilot a strategy to remove the social, economic and environmental constraints that currently do not allow the extremely poor smallholders benefited by the two programs to exit the cash transfer program, improve their livelihoods and achieve their human development.  In this manner, the project expects to generate a methodology that will enable the development of an exit strategy and at the same time harmonizing the implementation of the two programs.  This will be achieved through the following outcomes: 1) Institutional capacities strengthened to mainstream pro-poor, gender responsive and environmentally sustainable outcomes into the TEKOPORA and PPA programs; 2) Strengthening of the social and human capital, capacity development and empowerment of local stakeholders to increase opportunities for socio-economic and environmental integration and participation in local development agendas; 3) Sustainable inclusive businesses through public-private partnerships, environment-friendly agricultural production, natural resources conservation/management and microenterprises, for food production and income generation.

The general objective of the project is the improvement of recyclers, both women and men, wellbeing through the transformation of the waste management system towards an integrated pro-poor system, with emphasis on the empowerment of women recyclers based on the baseline information obtained, and the development of a more accessible and competitive recycling market for the poor. An environmental and recycling culture will be created through volunteering.

Knowledge, capacities and strategies will be created for the integration of social, poverty and gender variables into the planning processes of the integrated solid waste management at national and local (in Arequipa as pilot) levels.  Synergies between the gradual formalization of recyclers and environmental, social and economic opportunities will be identified and pursued. For many marginalized groups of the population, working in the solid waste sector represents an adaptive answer to avoid extreme poverty. The transformation towards a social inclusive and integrated waste system, promoting pro-poor opportunities in the recycling market, facilitates the creation of high quality jobs. Furthermore, the establishment of a sustained process of capacity-building of poor and vulnerable recyclers, both women and men, will lead to their integration in a more sustainable and competitive recycling market, while at the same time improving their wellbeing. The empowerment of women recyclers is a special focus of interest within the project, strengthening their capacity, promoting their leadership in the solid waste management, and creating conditions to ensure their participation in decision-making about their livelihoods. Special attention will be given to replication opportunities in other regions and at national level. With the contribution of United Nations Volunteers, the project will promote an environmental friendly and segregation culture through a local volunteering approach and citizen participation with a gender perspective.  
The 5 principal results of the project are:
1.	Strengthened institutional capacity of the Ministry of the Environment through the integration of social, poverty and gender variables into the solid waste management system of Peru;  
2.	Strengthened institutional capacity of the Provincial Municipality of Arequipa to improve the integrated management of solid waste through the incorporation of social, poverty and gender variables in local policies, instruments and tools.  
3.	Strengthened recyclers associations and favorable conditions towards long term financial sustainability;  
4.	The population of Arequipa mobilized and a waste-friendly and recycling culture generated through volunteering.
5.	Project management and the experiences of the project have been systematized and replication opportunities have been promoted.
